stem: After reviewing the client's electronic health record (EHR), match each fetal heart rate (FHR) deceleration pattern to its most likely cause.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
1400: SBAR for pt. Jane Doe, G1P0 at 39 weeks gestation. Admitted at 1300 due to spontaneous rupture of membranes. Fluid was clear. 

1405: Continuous EFM initiated. Baseline FHR is 135 bpm with moderate variability. 

1415: Cervical exam reveals 4 cm dilation, 70% effacement, and -2 station. 

1430: Noted FHR decelerations that mirror contractions, with onset and recovery coinciding with the start and end of the contractions. 

1445: Repositioned patient to left lateral position. 

1500: Continued monitoring reveals FHR decelerations that are abrupt and variable in timing, not consistently related to contractions. Some decelerations drop to 90 bpm for 30 seconds.

1515: Noted several late decelerations, with the deceleration onset occurring after the peak of the contraction. Lowest point reaching 110 bpm. 

1530: Notified Dr. Smith about the late decelerations. Oxygen via face mask at 10 L/min initiated. 

1545: Dr. Smith at bedside. Orders received (see orders tab).

1600: Amnioinfusion initiated per order. Continuous monitoring continues.

1615: Variable decelerations noted to be improving, but late decelerations persist. 

1630: Dr. Smith considering delivery options based on fetal response to interventions.

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: 13:00 HR: 88 bpm BP: 120/80 mmHg RR: 18 breaths/min Temp: 98.6°F (37°C) SpO2: 99% on room air FHR: 135 bpm 14:00 HR: 90 bpm BP: 122/82 mmHg RR: 20 breaths/min Temp: 98.7°F (37.1°C) SpO2: 98% on room air FHR: 135 bpm 15:00 HR: 94 bpm BP: 128/86 mmHg RR: 22 breaths/min Temp: 98.9°F (37.2°C) SpO2: 97% on room air FHR: Variable, with drops to 90 bpm 16:00 HR: 96 bpm BP: 130/88 mmHg RR: 24 breaths/min Temp: 99.0°F (37.2°C) SpO2: 98% on 10L O2 via face mask FHR: 110 bpm, late decelerations

tabs.title: Lab Results
tabs.content: 13:30 CBC: WBC: 12,000/μL (4,500-11,000/μL) Hgb: 12.5 g/dL (12-16 g/dL) Hct: 37% (36-48%) Platelets: 250,000/μL (150,000-400,000/μL) Urinalysis: Protein: Trace Glucose: Negative Ketones: Negative Leukocyte Esterase: Negative Nitrites: Negative

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content: 13:00 General: Patient alert and oriented, appears anxious. CV: Regular rate and rhythm, S1 and S2 auscultated. Resp: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally. Abd: Fundal height consistent with gestational age. Uterine contractions palpable. GU: Spontaneous rupture of membranes noted. Clear fluid. Cervix 4 cm dilated, 70% effaced, -2 station. Extremities: No edema noted. DTRs 2+ bilaterally.

tabs.title: Care Plan
tabs.content:
1545:
1. Oxygen via face mask at 10 L/min
2. Continuous Electronic Fetal Monitoring (EFM)
3. Amnioinfusion: 500 mL bolus of normal saline, then 150 mL/hr
4. Reposition patient to left lateral position.
5. Notify physician of any further decelerations.

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content: Normal Saline - 500 mL bolus IV, then 150 mL/hr (Amnioinfusion) - Ongoing

rows.text: Fetal heart rate decelerations that mirror the contractions. Onset and recovery of the deceleration coincide with the start and end of the contraction.
Fetal heart rate decelerations that are abrupt and variable in timing, not consistently related to contractions. Some decelerations drop significantly below the baseline.
Fetal heart rate decelerations with the onset occurring after the peak of the contraction.

rationale.correct: Early decelerations are caused by fetal head compression. Variable decelerations are caused by umbilical cord compression. Late decelerations are caused by uteroplacental insufficiency.
rationale.incorrect: Fetal head compression causes early decelerations. Umbilical cord compression causes variable decelerations. Uteroplacental insufficiency causes late decelerations. Misidentifying these causes would lead to incorrect interventions and potentially compromise fetal well-being.

answerBreakdown.text: Fetal heart rate decelerations that mirror the contractions. Onset and recovery of the deceleration coincide with the start and end of the contraction.
answerBreakdown.rationale: These are early decelerations, which are caused by fetal head compression during contractions. The deceleration mirrors the contraction, indicating a vagal response to pressure on the fetal skull.

answerBreakdown.text: Fetal heart rate decelerations that are abrupt and variable in timing, not consistently related to contractions. Some decelerations drop significantly below the baseline.
answerBreakdown.rationale: These are variable decelerations, which are caused by umbilical cord compression. The abrupt onset and variable timing are characteristic of cord compression, which can occur at any point during a contraction or between contractions.

answerBreakdown.text: Fetal heart rate decelerations with the onset occurring after the peak of the contraction.
answerBreakdown.rationale: These are late decelerations, which are caused by uteroplacental insufficiency. The delayed onset after the peak of the contraction indicates that the fetus is not receiving adequate oxygen due to reduced blood flow to the placenta.

clinicalPearls: VEAL CHOP is a mnemonic for understanding fetal heart rate decelerations: Variable decelerations - Cord compression; Early decelerations - Head compression; Acceleration - Okay; Late decelerations - Placental insufficiency.
Repositioning the mother is often the first intervention for variable decelerations, as it can relieve pressure on the umbilical cord.
Late decelerations require prompt intervention to improve placental blood flow, such as administering oxygen and IV fluids.

questionTrap.trap: Students often confuse variable and late decelerations. Both can be concerning, but their causes and interventions differ significantly.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Focus on the timing of the deceleration in relation to the contraction. Variable decelerations are abrupt and not related to contractions, while late decelerations occur after the peak of the contraction.

mnemonic.title: VEAL CHOP
mnemonic.expansion: Variable decelerations - Cord compression; Early decelerations - Head compression; Acceleration - Okay; Late decelerations - Placental insufficiency.
